importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date of the news report's publication indicates the most recent update on the investigation into Brett James' plane crash, signaling ongoing public interest and official inquiry.
This is the date of the incident when Brett James' plane crashed, marking the critical event that prompted the NTSB investigation and public attention.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The period between the crash and the report highlights the timeline of the investigation and public response, illustrating how quickly a major incident is assessed and communicated.

keyTakeAways: Brett James, a Grammy-winning songwriter known for collaborations with Taylor Swift, Bon Jovi, Keith Urban, and Kenny Chesney, died in a plane crash on September 18, 2025, in Franklin, North Carolina.

The National Transportation Safety Board (NTSB) reported that the plane entered a 'tightening spiral' after James failed to maintain proper radio communication with air traffic control, despite being instructed to tune to a common traffic advisory frequency.
James requested a visual approach to runway 7, which was approved, but never changed his radio frequency, leading to a loss of communication and a sequence of flight errors.
The Cirrus SR22T plane had no mechanical issues according to NTSB examination of the wreckage.
All three people on board were killed in the crash, underscoring the tragic outcome of a flight incident that may have been caused by procedural error or miscommunication.

James was a prominent figure in country music, with a major breakthrough in 2005 with the song 'Jesus, Take the Wheel' for Carrie Underwood, and was considered one of the industry’s most sought-after songwriters.

namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: James failed to tune to CTAF, leading to loss of communication, which is a key technical detail in the accident analysis.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Grammy-winning songwriter Brett James, known for his collaborations with Taylor Swift, Bon Jovi, Keith Urban, and Kenny Chesney, died in a plane crash on September 18, 2025, when his Cirrus SR22T aircraft entered a 'tightening spiral' after failing to maintain proper radio communication with air traffic control. The National Transportation Safety Board's preliminary report indicates that James, flying on a visual approach to runway 7 in Franklin, North Carolina, never changed his radio frequency despite being instructed to do so, leading to a loss of communication and a sequence of flight errors. No mechanical issues were found in the aircraft. The incident highlights a critical lapse in aviation protocol and underscores the tragic loss of a highly influential figure in country music.
title: Songwriter Brett James’ plane entered a 'tightening spiral' before crashing, the NTSB said in a preliminary report
